dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Christmas card vista is spoiled by a black line of railroad tracks stitched onto the snowy landscape like a scar pointing north to icy desolation. A phone rings -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elderly man who lives alone in this rustic cabin - a retired policeman - regards the phone, both expecting and dreading the call. He picks up the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.    White.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the frame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Postmark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henrik Vanger - at 82, even older than Morell - listens to the silence from his end of the line in a wood-paneled room as baronial as the policeman's was spartan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'm sorry, Henrik. There's nothing more to say. Vanger sets the receiver down and regards a dried white flower in a 6" x 11" frame resting on the brown paper it was wrapped and mailed in. It's somehow ominous, like the dark storm clouds that now burst outside -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikael Blomkvist - 40's - regards the gauntlet of reporters he'll have to pass to get out of the building. As he strides toward them, microphones and cameras swing in his direction. Without stopping -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, the media event of the year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to play it down, Mikael, it won't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to play it up, that won't either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling a bit like he's fleeing the scene of a crime, which in a way he is, Blomkvist steps outside opening his umbrella. A couple of the reporters come out after him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you appeal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll appeal to you, Viggo:   Find a real story to cover. He hurries off in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Financial journalist Mikael Blomkvist was found guilty today on 16 counts of aggravated libel against financier Hans-Erik Wennerstrom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a table with a pre-made sandwich and cup of coffee, and a long court judgement, Blomkvist watches himself fleeing the reporters on the cafe's TV. He's the only one there who watches it - no one else is interested - which only makes it worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an article published earlier this year, Blomkvist claimed Wennerstrom - founder and president of The Wennerstrom Group - used State funds intended for industrial development in Poland for an arms deal with the right-wing Ustashe in Croatia. The report cuts to a shot of Wennerstrom outside the courthouse in an Armani suit, surrounded by his legal team, confidently addressing the reporters -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing against Mr. Blomkvist. He's a good journalist who I don't believe is guided by malice. But what he wrote was inaccurate, and inaccuracies can't go unanswered. He - all journalists - have to accept like the rest of us, actions have consequences. Done with his sandwich, Blomkvist goes to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlboro Red ... and a lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes out tamping the pack. Extracts a cigarette. Tosses the pack in a sidewalk trash bin. Flicks at the lighter but can't get it to fire in the wind and rain. Hunches his body around it, coaxes it to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blomkvist was ordered to pay 600 thousand SKE in damages and all court costs, which could be significantly more. He takes a long drag that dizzies him. A wonderful feeling. He regards the trash bin. Fishes around it, finds the pack, puts it in his coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes through past Christmas decorations and a mostly- young staff. They try not to regard him as a dead-man- walking, but aren't entirely successful. He enters the editor's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you been? Erika Berger is about Blomkvist's age, and - like the IKEA furniture - sends a mixed message: a feminist in a mini-skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking.    Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one. He sits, exhausted and depressed, in a cheap Poang chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV4 called. I told them no statement until we've read the judgment in its entirety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have.    Who else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone who's ever wanted to see you humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been on the phone all day then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm as much to blame for this as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are?    You wrote it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read it.    I ran it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our credibility isn't dead, Mikael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine is. They regard each other in another silence.      Then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired. I feel like climbing under a duvet and sleeping for a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone? He thinks about it ... shakes his head `no.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already called Greger and told him I wouldn't be home tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motorcycle dives down a driveway that burrows under a three-story building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragan Armansky, 40's, who looks more like a boss of a New Jersey crime family than CEO of a high-tech security firm, sits behind his desk, waiting with an older client.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible we could wait forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called her, I thought.     You spoke to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that doesn't mean much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one here likes her. So it's better if she works at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you told her I wanted to meet her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've told her many more times I prefer her not to meet clients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure from the motorcycle crosses the lobby. From behind we can't see him/her well, but can see wary looks from others emerging from and getting into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very much. She's one of the best investigators I have. As you saw from her report -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The report on Armansky's desk is 200 pages long. INSERT: Printed on its cover: Mikael Blomkvist, a case number and, smaller, its author, Lisbeth Salander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm concerned you won't like her. She's different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In every way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black-clad figure - from behind again - strides past coworkers who look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Salander's here. Armansky breathes a defeated sigh, taps the intercom button twice to say `okay, let her in.' Lisbeth Salander walks in: A small, pale, anorexic- looking waif in her early 20's. Short black-dyed hair - pierced eyelid - tattoo of a wasp on her neck; probably several more under her black leather jacket - black t- shirt, black jeans, black Caterpillar boots. Frode is only middlingly successful in concealing his initial reaction to her. This isn't punk fashion. This is someone saying, Stay the fuck away from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisbeth, Mr. Dirch Frode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't shake Frode's hand, but does address him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong with the report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It seems quite thorough. There's a wealth of data here. But I'm also interested to know what's not in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing not in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your opinion of him isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not paid to give my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't have one? Salander sends Armansky a weary look. His look back begs her not to say anything unpleasant. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's clean.   In my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's - excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's honest. He's who he presents himself to be. In his business, that's an asset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's less in his asset column after his conviction today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true. He made a fool of himself with that. If it happened that way. Frode looks at Armansky.    What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he made up the story, that's out of character. So is giving up without a fight. People don't do things that are out of character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying he was set up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't part of my assignment. And, apparently, she has no opinion on it either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're quite right he made a fool of himself professionally. How big of a fool did he make of himself financially?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judgement will just about empty his savings. This seems to please Frode more than anything else that has been said, and Salander sees it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your report is light in another area. His personal life. Anything you chose not to include?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing that warranted inclusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure if that means yes or no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think what Ms. Salander means, and I agree, is that everyone has a right to a certain amount of privacy, even when they're being investigated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in this case. I have to know if there's anything about him I might find unsavory - even if she doesn't. Armansky's look to her at once apologizes for Frode, and encourages her to speak. She finally relents but puts no more spin on it than any other piece of raw data -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's had a long sexual relationship with his co-editor. It wrecked his marriage, but not hers. Her husband accepts it. Sometimes she sleeps at Blomkvist's, sometimes at home. Frode thinks about that, perhaps imagining how much simpler his own life would be with such an arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right not to include that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please think before you say no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be surprised by something later. Salander offers nothing more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Nothing else. In the personal department. You're sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blomkvist isn't sentimental, but does have a few framed snapshots: his daughter, his sister, and one with Erika - in their 20's - in which he's wearing a black leather jacket. She wakes up alone in his bed. Pads to the darkened living room to find him typing on his laptop, a half- eaten sandwich and glass of water next to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Usually when I wake up in a cold bed, it's at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Writing the press release.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saying -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're taking over as publisher. You're sorry for any nuisance Wennerstrom was caused. I can't be reached for comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're giving up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just taking a few steps aside. For you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This makes me sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salander sits alone at a table waiting for someone with a coffee and a gift haphazardly wrapped with a Christmas bow, the price tag still on it, a paperback book - My 60 Memorable Games, by Bobby Fischer. She notices the price tag is still on it. Peels it off. Dials a call on her cell. Hangs up when it goes to voice mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knocks on a door. Hears classical music playing softly inside, but no one answers. She tries the door. It's unlocked. The gift in hand, she pushes it open. She comes into an apartment which looks like it could belong to a professor. Sees a chess piece on the floor. Then a trail of them that lead her to an overturned chess table and, next to it, a body. The gash on the old man's head could have been caused by a fall into the corner of the table, or from a blow to it. She quickly tries to determine if he's breathing. Calls for an ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's doubtful there's a stranger Christmas gathering going on anywhere in the world. Standing around with eggnog are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blomkvist; his teenage daughter Pernilla; his sister Annika and her Italian husband; Erika and her weirdly understanding artist husband Greger, whose arm is around her waist; a few other friends (and perhaps lovers). GREGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You needed a better attorney.       You needed your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She offered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He declined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she hoped. ANNIKA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never a good idea mixing family and business. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I still would have lost. GREGOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have ... anything on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a lot.    It just wasn't any good. ERIKA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't even about Mikael. It was Wennerstrom sending a message to the press as a whole - and the FSA: Don't ask questions. Blomkvist's daughter seems concerned for him. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, Nilla. You don't have to worry about me. PERNILLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom's worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About me? PERNILLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About all that money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the ICU, Salander sits on the floor like a dog who won't leave the spot its master told it to wait. For the first time since we've met her, she looks vulnerable. The doors swing open. A doctor steps out. Salander gets up to hear his report -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Mr. Palmgren's daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His ward.   He doesn't have a daughter. The doctor isn't sure then if he should talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not allowed to go inside, she peers through glass at Palmgren, who is unaware of her, or the nurse attending him, or even himself. A spiderweb of tubes emerge from his neck and wrists; oxygen tubes from his nostrils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's had severe cerebral hemorrhaging. Either from the fall itself, or a stroke that led to the fall. His blood pressure is still high. I'm hopeful he'll regain consciousness, but that's not assured. And it's possible, if he does, there will be neurological damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're around the dinner table now, passing platters around. Blomkvist notices his daughter's head is bowed in silent prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nilla?    What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragon Tattoo Final 9/1/11 SZ PERNILLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about it since I know you won't approve. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of - (she doesn't say) Nilla. PERNILLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light of Life. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light of - what? (she doesn't repeat it) What is that? PERNILLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it's all senseless but it isn't. It's more natural to believe in something than not to. She begins eating. Blomkvist stares at her, feeling a little sick. A cell phone rings. No one can tell - as you never can - whose it is, and so all pull them out. It's Blomkvist's. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Looking back at his daughter with some concern, he steps away to take the call. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. FRODE O/S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Blomkvist? BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. FRODE O/S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me for intruding on your Christmas. My name is Dirch Frode. I'm an attorney. I represent Henrik Vanger. Perhaps you've heard of (him) - BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. FRODE O/S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd like to speak to you about a private matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you're calling at an awkward time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm about to sit down to Christmas dinner myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're referring to your recent legal trouble. That has provided Mr. Vanger with some entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't care for Wennerstrom either. Frode, in his polite, deliberate way, is reeling Blomkvist in like a perch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have him call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd like to meet in person if that's okay. Up north. Hedestad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's much too old to make a trip to Stockholm, Mr. Blomkvist. Please. If you'd be so kind as to consider. Blomkvist isn't sure what to do, or say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hedestad is lovely in winter.      Like a Christmas card.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKHOLM
dialogues.text: Salander rides a crowded underground train, but feels even more cut off from the people around her than usual; completely alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A passenger train, barely visible in a severe snowstorm, makes its way north. This is no Christmas card.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Blomkvist stares out at the bleak, northern landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blomkivist disembarks to find Frode - who he can only assume is Frode - beyond a veil of snow, waving to him from outside a Mercedes. Unlike Blomkvist, he's dressed for this God-awful weather in a fur-collared topcoat.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MERCEDES / HEDESTAD
dialogues.text: Frode's Mercedes comes across a long bridge linking the old industrial town to a rocky island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time in Hedestad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And last, I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lovely in the spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said it was lovely in winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is unseasonable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be on the 4:30 train back to Stockholm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless we get snowed in ... I'm joking. You'll be home tonight, if that's what you wish.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MERCEDES
dialogues.text: The car comes up a long, bare-tree-lined drive, leading to a stately manor. As Frode and Blomkvist climb out, a distant gunshot echoes, but neither Frode nor the old man who appears at the front door of the manor pays it any attention; just someone hunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome.   Come inside.    It's warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is warm inside. There are fires in the fireplaces. And Vanger himself is warm in nature, yet speaks quickly as they come through the house -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming way out here. Anna, take Mr. Blomkvist's insufficient coat. Would you like to freshen up? We'll be having dinner later. For now, hot tea is waiting. Unless you'd like a drink instead. What would you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Blomkvist would like to be on the 4:30 train back to Stockholm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stay for dinner. Vanger looks thoroughly disappointed.      Or hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I guess I'd better be quick then. Thank you, Dirch. Mikael, this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea service and pastries on a coffee table separate Blomkvist from Vanger, whose elderly frame is in danger of being swallowed up by a wing-back chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you used to run one of the biggest industrial firms in the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to.   That's correct. There are framed black and white photographs on a wall - factories and trains figuring into all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My grandfather forged the tracks the 4:30 train will take you home on - and most of the other pre-state-owned rail lines.   We stitched this country together. We made the steel and milled the lumber that built modern Sweden. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what our most profitable product now is? (Blomkvist doesn't)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fertilizer. Blomkvist imagines he's meant to offer a wistful shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not obsessed with the declining health of the company, but I am with the settling of accounts - and the clock is ticking. I need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officially, assisting me with my memoirs. But what you'd really be doing is solving a mystery. And you'd do that by doing what you do so well - this recent legal mishap of yours notwithstanding. You'd be investigating thieves, misers, bullies, and malcontents - the most detestable collection of people you'll ever meet ... my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exhumes an unwashed bowl from a sinkful of dirty dishes, fills it with tap water without rinsing it, dumps a packet of ramen noodles in, puts it in a microwave. She takes a Coke can from an anemically-stocked fridge to a desk in her so-called living room, a clutter of full ashtrays, fast food wrappers, empty soda cans, paperwork, unwashed laundry. The only things of any value here are her MacBook and several external hard drives. NOTE:   Changes below are INSERTS only:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She types Dirch Frode in the search window. Clicks on the top result which takes her to Frode's bio on Vanger Industries' site with its distinctive V.I. logo. His official company photo accompanies his profile: Uppsala University Law School ... Assistant Counsel, Vanger Industries, 1965-1972 ... Head Counsel, 1972- present. She types in another search - Hans-Erik Wennerstrom. Clicks on his Wikipedia page, which shows a photo of him alongside his bio. She skims it - President of the investment firm, Wennerstrom-gruppen ... personal wealth of 12 billion dollars (80 billion kronor) ... 82-foot yacht, villa on the island of Varmdo ... She does a third search, types: Wennerstrom+Vanger Industries - and hits the `cached' option - There are only a couple of results that include both terms. She goes to one of them, a body of text of some old page with the cached terms highlighted in yellow and blue, and reads - ... Hans-Erik Wennerstrom, CPA, Vanger Industries Accounting Dept., 1971-1972 ... Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children of the "thieves, misers, bullies and incompetents" play on a beach. A shutter blinks freezing a 12-year-old girl in foreground in black and white -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Harriet. The granddaughter of my brother Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same photograph of Harriet in a photo album Vanger shows Blomkvist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, who I may as well start with to get it out of the way, was a Nazi of the first order - joining the Nationalist Socialist Freedom League when he was 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A page in the album turns to reveal a photo of a young man in a uniform with a Nazi pin. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it interesting how fascists always steal the word freedom. (Blomkvist checks his watch) The 4:30. Yes. Okay. Anyway, Richard died a martyr to the Nazi cause in 1940 - missed all the real excitement - but not the opportunity to regularly beat his wife Margareta and their son, Gottfried. We see photos of Gottfried, a handsome young man. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Gottfried - Harriet's father - was what people used to call a Good- Time-Charlie. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're still called that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they?   Okay. INSERT:   Close on a photo of Gottfried. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a charmer, a ladies man, a drunk. In other words, a born salesman - which is what he did for the company - traveling around, taking clients out to dinner and so on. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone has to do it. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Anyway, he died in 1965. Drowned. Drunk. Here on the island. A studio photo: Gottfried with his wife and two children. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife Isabella - who was pretty much useless before as a parent - became even more so after his death - which is when I began looking after their children - Martin - who runs Vanger Industries now that I'm retired - and Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photo of a much younger Vanger and 15-year-old Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was bright and curious, a winning combination in any person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And beautiful. Vanger nods as he regards the photo ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something happened to her? Vanger nods again; is silent for several moments ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone in the family murdered Harriet and for the last forty years has been trying to drive me insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 4:30 train leaves the station without Blomkvist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna gathers the cups and leaves with the tea tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was September 21st, 1966.    A Saturday. Harriet was 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three generations of Vangers dot the grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brothers - along with their wives, children and grandchildren - had gathered here for our loathsome annual board meeting and dinner. It was also the day the Yacht Club held its Autumn parade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see the parade, and, among the spectators lining the town's main street, Harriet with other teenage girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet and a couple of school friends had gone into town to watch it. She returned a little after two o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clock in the room reads, 2:10.    Vanger and a few fami members sip afternoon cocktails.    Harriet appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She came to the parlor. She asked if she could talk to me. I honestly don't remember what I was doing that I thought was more important, but I told her to give me a few minutes. She leaves.   He returns to the others in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But in a few minutes, before I could go upstairs to talk to her, something else occurred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car and a fuel truck, both going too fast, collide on the bridge. The truck rolls onto its side crushing the car and spewing gasoline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The accident had nothing to do with Harriet - and everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanger and the others react to the noise of the crash. Out the large window they can see the bridge and many of those on the grounds trotting down to get a closer look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was chaos as everyone dropped what they were doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People and vehicles converge on both sides of the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police, an ambulance, fire brigade, reporter, photographer and onlookers quickly arrived from town, as those of us on the island - the family - hurried to the bridge from our side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck driver has managed to climb out of his cab, but the other motorist is trapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver of the car - a Mr. Aronsson - was pinned and severely injured. All we could do was try to pry him out with our hands - since metal tools could spark. A local newspaper photographer and another man, snap pictures as Vanger and others try without success to pry the injured driver from his car. As the chaos ensues -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About twenty minutes after the crash, Harriet was in the kitchen. Anna herself saw her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna glances to Harriet as she comes in, then back out the window to the bridge. Harriet passes a clock that reads 2:35, steps outside, walks toward the woods ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the sun sets, Vanger and the others on the bridge make progress extracting the driver from the car. A young man coming from the town side takes off his jacket to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We finally got poor Aronsson out of his car and off to the hospital, and those of us on our side drifted back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family has assembled at a long dining table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun was down, the excitement over, we sat down to dinner. That's when I noticed Harriet wasn't there. Vanger considers an empty chair as everyone else, including the young man from the bridge, his jacket draped on his chair, passes platters of food around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she wasn't there the next morning. Or the next. Or the next forty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanger has the same look of concern on his face now as he leads Blomkvist up some stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was she going to tell me? Why didn't I make time for her? Why didn't I listen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She couldn't have run away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not without being seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crews continue their work under lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firemen stayed on the bridge all night pumping out the gasoline. And no one swam across, or took a row boat. All of them were still tied up on this side Sunday. Believe me, we checked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She couldn't have fallen and drowned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The currents aren't strong here. Anything that falls into the water turns up nearby. Like her father. His body didn't drift more than ten meters when he drowned the year before. Vanger's pauses at a landing to steady himself and his labored breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Someone killed her, Mr. Blomkvist. Someone on the island that day. Someone close enough to know what she used to give me each year on my birthday. He unlocks the door of the attic and pushes it open to reveal a cluster of nine dusty framed dried flowers on a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These were from her. And, on another wall, forty similarly-framed flowers -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These, from her killer. Blomkvist regards the forty ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows about these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, the police, the murderer ... and now you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining as an elegantly-dressed woman slows before a luxurious apartment building. Salander approaches from the other direction. Passing, she notes the four number tones the woman keys in the code lock. The door buzzes open and the woman disappears inside. Salander doubles back and keys the same four number tones in the Milton Security lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opulent foyer. Security camera. Antique elevator cage whose cables pull the woman upstairs. Salander comes to an unlocked service door and takes stairs to a basement machine room. Examines tangles of phone lines, meters, Wi-Fi routers. Photographs them with a digital camera. She climbs the stairs back up to the foyer. The front door buzzes, and a man in a suit on the sidewalk pushes it open, sees her, holds it wide enough for her to pass. The man is a driver/bodyguard. He continues to hold the door for his employer who now emerges from the back of an idling car and crosses to it in the rain ... Wennerstrom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain here is icier and more punishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the police investigation petered out, I kept at it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're eating dinner now in the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - studying their reports and interviews, all the information there was, and it's a lot. I've spent half my life examining the events of a single day. And for all that, he's no closer to the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand your frustration. But what you're asking me to do is a waste of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't discussed your fee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't need to. I can't find something you haven't been able to in forty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that. You have a very keen investigative mind. Blomkvist wonders why he ever agreed to come here as Vanger refills his wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's what I propose: You come stay on the island. I have a nice little cottage by the water you can use. You study the material I give you. You find something I've missed - or you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to set aside my life and career for something that's a complete waste of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of it as a well deserved vacation. A way of avoiding all the people you want to avoid right now. (nothing from Blomkvist)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As for compensation, I'll pay you twice your salary for as many months as it takes. I'll quadruple it if you solve the mystery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. (Vanger) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not done. I'll throw in one more thing - even though you're a terrible negotiator. It's what you want more than anything else and it can't be bought at any price. I'll give it to you ... Hans-Erik Wennerstrom. He pushes toward Blomkvist a plate: the carcass of the fresh-killed and cooked duck they've been eating. It and the mention of Wennerstrom's name clouds, at least for a moment, Blomkvist's memory of the train he missed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He began his career working for me. And I've followed it with interest, shall we say, ever since. You were right about him. You just couldn't prove it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salander climbs a flight of stairs in a building that couldn't be more different than Wennerstrom's. Knocks on a door, waits, listens to some dead-bolts unlocking. It opens, but remains impassable by a figure weighing over 300 pounds. He offers her no greeting. Fades back into the shadows of his dark apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to sit? I could possibly clear a place if necessary. It's hard to imagine how he or anyone might accomplish that. The place is like a junkyard. Even the unmade bed is covered with stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you make it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you something for me? She takes some cash from a pocket, hands it to him.    He counts it and is unimpressed with its total.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on welfare; I don't administer it. This isn't enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to pay three months back rent and eat a little bit. It's all I have right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find that so poignant. So much so that he does nothing more than look at her. She reaches to take the money back, but he pockets it and moves across the dark room to a work table where high-end computers fight for space with debris. Finds and gives her a small homemade electronic box, which she turns over in her hands. While it's clear both these people are deficient in behavior that governs polite society, it's hard to tell which lacks it more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No `thank you?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erika, first to arrive this morning, or so she thinks, comes through the empty offices with a Wayne's Coffee to- go cup - but Blomkvist is already there, packing supplies from his desk, books from his shelf. A second suitcase, presumably full of clothes, sits on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be serious -

dialogues.speaker: 51A INT/EXT. MILLENNIUM'S OFFICES
dialogues.text: He zips the suitcase with the supplies in it closed and gathers the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in our worst crisis ever and you're writing a memoir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fired me; I need something to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fired you; I need you here, not the North Pole. You know what this is going to look like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I've been gutted. Like I'm running away. I am. They cross through the building, he with his cases, she with her coffee cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wennerstrom wants to see me waving a white flag, not a red one. And the more it looks like there's a problem between you and me, the more it'll satisfy him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a problem between us. He won't be satisfied until he shuts us down, and you're leaving me to fight him alone. He kisses her but gets back no more than he would from a statue - and steps outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's four hours by train.   It's not the North Pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The depot thermometer reads 0. Blomkvist disembarks with two suitcases. This time, Frode isn't there to meet him. He struggles with his luggage through the snow to a taxi stand.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: As a taxi passes a gas station by the bridge, Blomkvist regards the Middle Eastern driver's eyes which regard him in the rear view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think this snow's going to let up anytime soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the North Pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi deposits Blomkvist outside a cottage. From here he can see Vanger's manor and couple other houses. The taxi drives off and disappears into the snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two rooms. Fireplace. Pile of wood. A realtor would call it cozy. In truth it's just tiny and freezing cold. Blomkvist unpacks. Puts clothes in a wardrobe, sets out books, note pads, pens, CD's, a CD player, his laptop and a small printer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flips open his cell phone to make a call. Gets no reception bars. Hears a faint, plaintive cry and traces it to a window, beyond which, on the sill outside, stands a cat peering in. He opens the door, and the cat heads straight for the kitchenette. Then looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.   Milk? He opens the old fridge.    No milk.    Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes out into falling snow holding his cell phone out in front of him like a dowser divining ground water. Moves around trying to get a signal. Can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He purchases milk, butter, a loaf of sliced bread, some packaged lunch meats and a few cans of cat food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks along the street through wind-whipping snow, cradling the grocery bag, cell out in front of him again. Any of the locals could tell him he could do this forever - there are no cell towers anywhere around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grocery bag at his feet, he dials a call with fingers he can no longer feel on the gas station pay phone by the end of the bridge. It goes to Erika's voice mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me. I'm here. It's fucking cold and I'm on a pay phone. If you tried to call, the reception sucks, and if you tried to email, there's none of that either, so - so - I'm here - and - I can't even speak it's so fucking cold. He hangs up, open the same pack of cigarettes from before. Eighteen in there. Struggles to get one lit in the wind and snow, hurries off toward the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cat laps at milk on a plate, Blomkvist tries to get a fire going using pages ripped from a book. It's a struggle he's going to lose; he's no Boy Scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salander appears and keys in the four lock tones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the machine room again, she pulls one cable away from the others and wires to it to Plague's electronic box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell in the church tower clangs -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's a knock that draws Blomkvist awake. Having forgotten where he is, he regards the cat sleeping with him, then the room, and groans. He pads to the door in the freezing cold. Opens it to find a rugged older man on his doorstep with a handcart loaded with file boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Gunner.   The caretaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Gunner expertly builds a fire in the fireplace for him, Blomkvist works at unpacking the boxes - documents, fat police reports, notebooks, folders, photo albums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an author.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm writing a biography of Mr. Vanger, yes. Nilsson nods, but isn't sure he believes it. Maybe he took a look inside the boxes before he brought them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you on television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's unfortunate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bit of trouble, I guess. Blomkvist nods and hopes that's enough to put an end to the subject. It isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No jail time, though. That's good. Cost you a lot of money though, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blomkvist shares his annoyance with the cat. Nilsson dusts himself off, satisfied with the fire he's made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanger has ventured outside to show Blomkvist around the estate. Smoke from chimneys rise into bitter cold grey skies, weather for which Blomkvist, unlike the old man, is inadequately dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The island is owned by my family. Your closest neighbor is my brother Harald, another Nazi if you can believe. Two in the family. He's detestable to put it nicely, but you'll probably never see him. He's a recluse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was there that day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed he was. Vanger's look to Blomkvist adds, `so consider him a suspect.' He indicates another house on the grounds -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's his daughter Cecilia's house. They don't speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anyone speak to anyone on this island?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, Isabella - Harriet's mother - who lives there - (points)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - she speaks to Harald - which is one of reasons I don't speak to her. (points)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecilia's brother Birger lives there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who doesn't he speak to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, probably. Not that you'd want him to. He can be as unpleasant as Harald.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm quickly losing track who's who. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, how you'll wish were it always so. Soon you'll know us all only too well - with my apologies. (points) Out there is my nephew Martin's house; Harriet's brother. It's a modern house - lots of glass - out on the point. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who speaks to him? VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I speak to him. He runs the company now, as I think I told you. They hear a distant rifle crack and echo.     It startles Blomkvist a bit, but not Vanger. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone shooting their dinner. Gunner probably. The caretaker. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just met him. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was 19 when Harriet disappeared. Old enough, Blomkvist gathers, to be considered a suspect. Vanger points off - VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lives over there. Shivering in the cold, Blomkvist turns. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you live here. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry? BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your house. For a moment, Vanger isn't sure what Blomkvist means. Then he is, and is pleased by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you're right. The man who hires the detective should always be kept on the suspects list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nurse takes a tray away, leaving Salander alone with Palmgren, separated by the chess table they won't playing a game on. She wipes his mouth with her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a call from social welfare. I've been assigned a new guardian. It's unlikely he understands what she has said.        It unlikely he even knows she's there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tacked to a wall, a map of the island on which Blomkvist has written the names of the living Vanger family members and staff in the approximate locations of their houses. Next to it - 3x5 cards and photos - a Vanger family tree which doubles as a suspects list. On some of the cards is the word, `deceased.' He makes a sandwich. Refills a coffee cup. Begins reading the police reports. The first is a photocopy of a note when the call from Vanger came in: "Officer Morell informed by telephone of situation, 10:19 p.m."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gustaf Morell stands at the bow of a patrol boat slowly motoring past the bridge where the fire brigade works to pump the gasoline from the overturned truck. INTERCUT: Blomkvist reads, "Morell on site, Hedeby Island, 11:42 p.m."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morell, feeling like he's entered an Agatha Christie locked room mystery, regards the extended Vanger clan sitting in the living room looking suitably worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see the girl's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought this was your house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.    She lives with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are her parents alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mother is. Vanger points Isabella out. Slender, overdressed and smoking a Sobranie, she immediately strikes Morell as a woman as venomous as she is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way. Morell follows Vanger down a hall - INTERCUT: Blomkvist reads, "Approx. 12:05, inspected missing girl's bedroom. Found - "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A purse on the desk in Harriet's room. Morell carefully removes the contents: Comb, pocket mirror, handkerchief, wallet containing a few kronor, her ID, and her address book. He leafs through this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to speak to everyone here. That'll take all night so you might want someone to put some coffee on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the search?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First thing in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We should do it now. She could be hurt out there. Vanger is either a good actor or has nothing to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.   I beg you. INTERCUT: Blomkvist reads, "authorized our patrol boat and two volunteer craft to begin 12:20 a.m. - G. Morell."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police patrol boat and two Peterssons motor around the island, spotlighting the shore and rocky cliffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weird tableaux of characters, awaiting their interviews with Morell. At the moment, he's across the room with Harald Vanger, taking notes, drinking coffee. INTERCUT: Blomkvist reads, "Patrol 014 and Orienteering Club volunteers assembled, 6:40 a.m."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Search parties crisscross the island, wade through ditches, check old barns, shine flashlights up chimneys. Woodsmen with blood hounds comb through woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We searched for days ...

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. TRAIN
dialogues.text: A train bisects the landscape.   Blomkvist looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eventually, much to his dismay - and mine - I had to talk to Henrik about calling it off -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the search continues, Morell, looking like he hasn't slept - which he hasn't - peers down a rocky cliff to the water. Somehow he knows they're never going to find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fact that I never found a body didn't surprise me. You can't dig up an entire island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same face - forty years older - the man who spoke to Vanger on the phone about the dried flowers - now speaks with Blomkvist as he scrapes out the bowl of his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But   I also couldn't find a motive. Was   it spontaneous? Was it planned? Did   she know something someone wished she   didn't? Was it about business? BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business?   She was sixteen. MORELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And very bright. Henrik told me he could easily imagine her running the business someday, which would mean someone else wouldn't. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was with some friends that day. At a parade. You must have talked to them. MORELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told them she wasn't feeling well. She left early. But they also said she kept secrets from them, too. The main thing I learned talking to them for hours is that teenage girls are complicated. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have one. MORELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you know. (Blomkvist does indeed) Did you bring the last gift Henrik received? BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's at the National Forensic Lab. MORELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you what their report will say now: It's a flower common to Europe. All of them are. No prints. No DNA. He lights the pipe.   Blomkvist watches the tobacco glow. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to ask you about this. He produces an old address book from his jacket pocket. Of course, Morell has seen it before, and handles it delicately. The decades have dried out its pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragon Tattoo Final 9/1/11 SZ MORELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She received this from Henrik the Christmas before. I studied it more times than I can say. I know every page of it. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the last page I'm curious about. MORELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As was I. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only names not alphabetized. Morell nods that he knows that only too well as he turns to that last page. On it, in neat handwriting: Magda 32016 Sara 32109 R.J. 30114 R.L. 32027 Mari 32018 MORELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're local Hedestad phone numbers. The first belonged to a woman named Margot, whose mother was Magda, who claimed she didn't know Harriet. The fourth, R.L., belonged to Rosemarie Larsson, an elderly woman who died a few years before. The other three were unconnected in any way that I could find. He hands the address book back. It, and everything else about the case, clearly trouble him still. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've reminded you of things you'd rather forget. I'm sorry. MORELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't forget it. It's my Rebecka Case. Blomkvist isn't sure what that means. MORELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every policeman has at least one unsolved case. Back then it was old Torstensson. Year after year he kept returning to one - taking out the files - uselessly studying them. As young men, we had to laugh. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was this also a missing girl case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's not why I mention it. The Rebecka Case is something that happened before Harriet was born. I'm talking about the soul of a policeman. Poor Torstensson could never solve it, and could never let it go. And neither can poor Morell with his Harriet case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unexciting social welfare building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a man behind a desk reviews   a thick file, Salander reviews him: About 50; spends    money on suits, thinking that might disguise his public   servant status; no weddi ring; typical creep, as far as   she's concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Mr. Palmgren doing? I was told he had a stroke of some kind. (nothing from Salander)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrible. It is, but she can tell he couldn't care less.     He lea through her file -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly do you do at this security company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make coffee and sort mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not full-time. Not even part- time consistently. They somehow got along without coffee or mail in July and August? Nothing from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do you earn there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is your rent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragon Tattoo Final 9/1/11 SZ SALANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pay my rent. BJURMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the last time you were late? SALANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never. BJURMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that ring in your eyelid makes you attractive? Salander, who's had to suffer insufferable officials all her life, doesn't dignify the question with an answer. BJURMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the problem. There a discrepancy between the obligation of Mr. Palmgren's guardianship and the management of your finances. SALANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't a discrepancy or a problem. It was clear to him I could manage my own finances. BJURMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not clear to me. SALANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a child. BJURMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You're not. (looks at her too long) But you were. And between then and now - (indicating the files) - two years in the locked ward at St. Stephens, for violent aggression - failure to adapt to four foster homes and seven schools - arrested twice for intoxication, twice for narcotics use, and most recently for assault: a bottle smashed into a man's face. You may have conned Mr. Palmgren into thinking you've improved, but looking at this - (the file) - not to mention how you're looking at me now - I can see you haven't. So the Good-Old-Mr-Palmgren-Days are over. Starting now, you'll be given a monthly allowance. You'll provide me with receipts for your expenses. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the numbers don't balance, I'll have to assume the difference is going to drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been on my own since I was twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You've been a persistent burden to the State since you were twelve. She won't look at him any more - not that there's anything even remotely interesting to see if she did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Salander? Please look at me. Because this is important. She does ... in a way that says, I'd like to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This behavior you're displaying right now is elaborately documented here - (in the file)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - so it would come as a shock to no one if I chose an alternative to the lenient arrangement I just outlined. Is that what you're saying with your silence? You'd prefer institutionalization?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salander steps into the elevator, hits the down button. As the doors close -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin's house didn't look so far away, but the road Blomkvist has to climb to reach it, and the fact he, like all writers, is out of shape, taxes him. A car driven by an attractive woman in her 30's pulls alongside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikael? (he manages a nod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to the same place. Hop in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin, wearing an apron, opens the door to find both his dinner guests on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found him at death's door halfway up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I'm a bit out of shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's a climb for anyone. I should've warned you. Come on in. Blomkvist puts a bottle of aquavit in Martin's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is far cry from Vanger's manor. It's modern. Martin, Liv and Blomkvist work on the dinner Martin has prepared. Soft jazz music issues from somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to work in the company's petrochemical division in Goteborg. When it was sold, I went with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live in Hong Kong now, but come back to Stockholm for family events, and when I do, I drive up to spend a couple days with Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes for the moose steak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what this is? They all glance away to a sound: A soft, strange, wailing wind. Martin drains the last of a bottle of wine in Blomkvist's glass and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's open. You like this one, or would you like to try something else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one's good. Martin heads off to the kitchen. Blomkvist and Liv, left with each other, seem unsure what to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you on Sky News a while ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a dark day. LIV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to remind you of it. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. There are worse things than libel - though I can't immediately think of one in my business. LIV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're writing a book now, Martin said. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henrik's biography. LIV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love Henrik. He's fascinating. Martin, too. Together they're the Old Sweden and the New.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are. LIV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know about Harriet, right? Blomkvist doesn't say.    The sound of the wind stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. Martin emerges from the cellar with a bottle of wine in hand and returns with it to the dining room. LIV O/S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family doesn't like to talk about it, but it can't just be swept under the rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet. Martin doesn't comment.    Just nods.    Silence.   Then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragon Tattoo Final 9/1/11 SZ BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we could talk about that later. MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can talk about it now. (Blomkvist glances to Liv) Liv knows everything about my crazy family. Which is why she'll never marry me. LIV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one reason. She holds up her left hand. A wedding ring is on it. The couple seems very comfortable with each other, not unlike Blomkvist and Erika. MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't put that in your book. Anything else is fine. Harriet certainly. Everything changed after that. Not just the family, but the company. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so. MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not Nordea or Ericsson, but we're still the largest family-owned company in the country. At the height, we had 40,000 employees. We have about half that now, and that downward slide - anyone can tell you - began after my sister's death. It broke Henrik's entrepreneurial spirit, and his heart. And Martin's, too, clearly.    Blomkvist dares to ask, as innocently as possible - BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were here that day? MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone was here, though I didn't get in until after the accident on the bridge. The 4:30 train. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a terrible day. And the days after - searching and not finding her - were even worse. Liv sets her hand atop her boyfriend's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This event, Mikael, has to be a big part of your book. Blomkvist promises him with a nod that it will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Salander moves with a crowd toward the doors of a subway car, someone behind her roughly yanks the strap of her messenger bag from her shoulder - She gives chase, pushes past people, catches up with the junkie, grapples with him. He slugs her. She goes down, but doesn't give up. Catches up with him on the escalator, throws him back down it. The bag slams onto the metal stairs, too, but at least she has it now. She doesn't run. She waits at the top and watches the junkie drag himself up and think about trying again. He wisely decides to let it go, hops to the down-escalator and disappears into the underground station.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. COTTAGE
dialogues.text: Blomkvist sifts through a box containing some of Harriet's personal belongings: school papers, textbooks, a Bible, the address book, her wallet and ID ... A knock on the door. He puts the box in a closet on top of others, kicks it closed, opens the front door to find a not unattractive woman in her 50's on his porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I thought I'd come over and say hello. I'm Cecilia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecilia regards Blomkvist's Vanger family tree on the wall. Wherever he only has an old photo, there's a Post- It next to it that reads: Recent Photo? INSERT of Cecilia's photo, taken when she was a teenager, and a Post-It with her name on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all uncomfortable with the idea of a chronicle of our family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not about the family. It's about Henrik and the company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my intention to present a malicious portrait of anyone. CECILIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike the one that landed you in court. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike that one. Correct. CECILIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what you're saying is, you're not really here to look into what happened to Harriet. Silence.   Then - BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't ignore such a dramatic event, but no, that's not by any means my focus. CECILIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So all those boxes Gunner carted down here - which are where? - in the closet now? - weren't Henrik's private investigation. (Blomkvist can't think fast enough to respond) I wonder sometimes who's crazier - my Nazi father or my obsessed uncle. INSERT of the photo of Young Harald in his Nazi uniform on the wall. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since we're talking about it, since you brought it up, what was Harriet like? CECILIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure Henrik has told you. BLOMKVIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was my age then, and so couldn't know what was really going on with a teenager any more than I can with my own daughter. You were her age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, my sister Anita was closer to her in age. INSERT of the photo on the wall of Anita, taken when she was about 17 years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knew Harriet better than anyone - certainly better than I did. You should talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to, where is she.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had to guess - London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know where your own sister lives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen her in years.       We never really got along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting used to that comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way it is when you're always after the same boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People generally get over that sort of thing at a certain point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm long over it, and won't ever have to worry about it again. She hates this place even more than I do. She left, moved to London and that was it. You couldn't pay her to send a Christmas card, much less visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try to track her down for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For myself then. He smiles.    She studies him.      Maybe he's not so bad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you do, and try talking to her about us, don't be surprised if she tells you to fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tech tries to get beyond the dreaded blinking "?" on the laptop's cracked screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You backed up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard drives at home, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.    This one's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salander against the store window, cell phone to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, he's booked all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll take five minutes.      It's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold, please. Salander waits. Watches people stare at her like they always do. The secretary comes back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salander comes past a janitor waxing a long, otherwise empty corridor. At the far end, she opens her new guardian's office door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bjurman reviews a McJesus invoice, Salander waits. The thick atmosphere reminds her of all the others she has sat in with school principals, shrinks and cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever had an STD? (nothing from her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the last time you were tested for HIV?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragon Tattoo Final 9/1/11 SZ BJURMAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nothing) How many partners have you had in the last month? (nothing) How many were men? That last one seems to amuse him; none amuse her. BJURMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm required to ask you these things. It's a matter of health. SALANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write down anything you want. Bjurman sighs. Sets the form aside and looks at the McJesus invoice again. BJURMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you need such an expensive computer? SALANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For work. BJURMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making coffee and sorting mail. SALANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't even have to ask. I should have control of my money like before. BJURMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you will. Once you show me you can be sociable and get along with people. Can you do that? (nothing from her) Shall we start with me? (pause) Shall we start now? As he comes around the desk, she eyes a sharp letter opener sticking out above some pens in a coffee mug a child has painted with the word, `daddy.' BJURMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're nice to me, I'll be nice to you. That's how normal people are. He stands in front of her, his crotch at her eye level. BJURMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done this before.   You know what to do. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she doesn't do anything)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want this computer or not? He takes her hand and places it on the crotch of his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel that? That's gaberdine. Unzip them. (she does)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ... (she tugs at his underwear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ... (she doesn't move; he smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the reticence. I prefer a whore who pretends she isn't. It's almost convincing. He grabs her hair and roughly pulls her head toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salander eats some toothpaste in Bjurman's private bathroom. When she returns to the office, she finds him calmly writing a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go.   As promised. He holds it out to her, but when she reaches for it, pulls it back a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're not thinking about telling anyone about our date. Enjoy your computer games. She takes the check and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits cross-legged in the dark. Thinking. Or plotting. The dragon tattoo visible on her bare back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blomkvist, who doesn't care for flying, pours two mini- bottles of vodka into a plastic cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sprays Binaca in his mouth. Then, careful to look both ways, crosses the street to an investment bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blomkvist approaches a desk.       The brass name plate o reads, Anita Vanger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I'm sure I should have made an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine.    Please.     Have a seat. The accent is all British. She's been here much longer than her home country. No trace of Swedish anymore. He offers his hand -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mikael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikael.   How do you do. As he sits, she regards him a little more carefully ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking for investment counseling, Mikael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would if had any money to invest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm writing a biography of your uncle Henrik. That's why I'm here. She stares at him. He waits for the response Cecilia predicted, but it doesn't come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit together at a little table on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is Henrik?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.   Engaging. I like him. She does, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragon Tattoo Final 9/1/11 SZ

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: I haven't seen him in over 30 years. Or my sister. Or anyone else in my family.

dialogues.speaker: BLOMKVIST
dialogues.text: Most of what I'm writing about predates that, so your recollections are valid.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know where to start, if that was a question.

dialogues.speaker: BLOMKVIST
dialogues.text: I can narrow it. I've gotten up to the 1960s. To the event that altered everything in Henrik's life.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: Harriet. (he nods) Everything I knew about that I told to - whatever his name was - that policeman - when it happened.

dialogues.speaker: BLOMKVIST
dialogues.text: Morell.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: My recollections then were a lot better than they are now.

dialogues.speaker: BLOMKVIST
dialogues.text: I'm not speaking of the crime itself. I'm trying to get a clearer sense of what Harriet was like. Particularly, toward the end.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: She was messed up. Like all us Vanger kids. Crazy mother. Drunken father. At least hers wasn't a Nazi like mine.

dialogues.speaker: BLOMKVIST
dialogues.text: Was he abusive?

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: Mine?

dialogues.speaker: BLOMKVIST
dialogues.text: Hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw it myself, but you could tell something was going on. One day she'd be withdrawn. The next she'd be putting on makeup and wearing the tightest sweater she had to school. The next she'd be studying a Bible like a nun - no Vanger was ever religious - can you imagine? Obviously, she was very unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never confided in you what about, specifically?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no specifically. It was everything. It was being part of that family. Henrik's the only decent person in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think happened to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone knows what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have no ... thoughts about why, or who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is I always felt sorry for her. Even more than for myself. I got out of there when I was 18 and never went back. She would have done the same but didn't make it to 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
