dialogues.text: Salander, on a park bench, debates with herself if she wants to make the call on the cell in her hand. She scrolls to "NB" and hits send. It connects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bjurman, please. It's Lisbeth Salander. (the call is put through)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'm fine. I'm sorry I missed our appointment. I had a lot of work ... no, nothing to be concerned about ... I need another advance on my allowance. Can I come to your office tonight? ... I don't need a pen, what's the address?

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. HEDEBY ISLAND
dialogues.text: The taxi that first brought him here to the island, crosses the bridge. Again, Blomkvist regards the Middle Eastern driver, who regards him in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the building's entrance with a backpack slung over her shoulder, Salander presses an apartment button. As she waits, she notes there's no security camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door buzzes.     She pushes it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves along a hallway with both purpose and dread. Knocks on his door ... It opens, revealing him in a robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes in the layout quickly: living room, dining area, kitchen, short hallway to a closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's home. (pause) So, what do you need money for this time? Grand Theft Auto 5?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles.    Steps toward her.    Lifts her chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you? Been thinking about last time? Decided you wanted to see me again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see if I can help you out with that. He walks to the hallway. She doesn't. He holds out his hand. She finally joins him. As they step into the bedroom, he roughly pushes her toward the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. She puts her backpack and leather jacket on a chair. Sits on the edge of the bed. He stands over her. She knows what she's supposed to do, but seems unable to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to know, am I going to have to do this every time I need money to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so cute when you do that surly thing. Take my hand She reaches out to it and before she can react, there's a handcuff around the wrist. He quickly cuffs the other to his own wrist. This is bad. She tries to get out. He gets her in a strangle hold and chokes her into unconsciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes to, on her stomach, sees her wrists cuffed to the headboard posts, her ankles secured to the foot posts with silk ties, and scissors slicing her jeans off. She starts to scream and he stuffs her mouth with her underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.   I have neighbors. He lights a couple candles.   Switches on some New Age music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we're going to do now is teach you the value of money. He watches her struggle. But she's not going anywhere. He tears open a condom package with his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forget - did I ask you before if you liked anal sex? He crams a pillow under her stomach and climbs on top of her. She keeps fighting but there's not much she can do handcuffed. Eventually, she retreats to another place inside herself. She's had to go here before in her life; it's the only place to go in such situations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat turns its head to a sound Blomkvist can't hear. He has Harriet's box of belongings out again and looks at photos of her school friends in her wallet. Then picks up the Bible. Handwritten on the inside cover is Harriet Vanger. He opens it at random. Hebrews:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith is the assurance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen. Through faith we understand that the world was created by the word of God - and that what is seen was not made of things that are visible ... He sets it down. Rubs his eyes. Everything - his daughter, his life, this cabin, the word of God - is depressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn light outside the living room window. Bjurman, at his dining table with a glass of orange juice, writing out a check. In the bedroom, Salander slips on her leather jacket, shoulders her backpack, hobbles out to the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drive you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get home on my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? It's bizarre: his manner seems to be one of genuine concern. She nods. He hands her the check. Then opens the door for her like a perfect gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, next Saturday, here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.   Leaves.   The door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone figure hobbles through the empty streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sets a check down. On the memo line he's neatly written, "for food." She takes a bottle of water from the fridge and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shower water hits the dragon tattoo on her shoulder blade and runs down past several others. By the time the water reaches the drain it has turned red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming through trees with a bag of groceries, Blomkvist sees a BMW parked outside his cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blomkvist taps on the car's fogged-up driver's window. A hand inside wipes at it, revealing Erika. She lowers it a crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it any warmer inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he tries to get some logs in the fireplace going, using more pages torn from one of his books, Erika wraps herself in a blanket. The cat, who has no trouble with the cold, naps on the paperwork on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have I missed besides you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The steady exodus of two-thirds of our advertisers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that hard to believe? Sitting up here in Lappland with your cat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.   I'm working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see. What she can see is the Vanger research covering the walls and table surfaces, and that the threads of the family tree lead to a photograph of Vanger at the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe in about an hour.      If you're interested. He is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanger and Martin all but ignore Blomkvist as they chat with Erika over dinner. They seem charmed by her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize if you're having financial problems at the magazine in Mikael's absence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll work through them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Erika looks at Blomkvist, but he hasn't talked to them about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do you think you can hang on? Six months or so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds about right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I used to be in the newspaper business. We owned six dailies back in the 50's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still own one. The Courier, here in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I let my nephew Birger run it since he can't run anything else. Erika nods politely. MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you say to taking on a partner? ERIKA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've never considered it before. We value our independence. MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your independence is dependant on advertisers - if we're being honest. However much you think that is, you'd retain. We don't care about content. Blomkvist suddenly feels like someone coming late to a party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.   Did I miss something? VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're talking about an investment in the magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gather.    Why would you want to do that? MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for the return, that's for sure. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Erika) I feel bad that I've take Mikael away from you at the worst possible time. This is the right thing to do. The moral thing. That's one reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enemies of my friends are my enemies. I hate Wennerstrom as much as you hate what he's done to you. Silence. VANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erika half-shrugs to say she'll consider it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful!   More wine, Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blomkvist looks at Erika, but she glances away to Vanger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Mikael is adapting well to rustic life, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen him try to make a fire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the logs on end, like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a teepee shape with his hands, like praying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erika lights a teepee of logs in the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been discussing this with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been. They asked me to come up yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I.   You live in the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I deserve to be treated like an idiot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to hear what they had to say. You would've said no before they could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying it now. It's not a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me tell them we could hang on for six months. I was lying. Without their money we'll be out of business in three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know this family.   They're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not marrying into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are if we do this. It's exactly what we're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to say no? Let's say no. Instead of 50 percent of something, let's own 100 percent of nothing. The logs crackle as flames climb them. She gets up, comes past him, unbuttoning her shirt as she disappears into the bedroom. He stares at the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving this God-forsaken island in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you coming to bed or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salander regards a selection of forearm tattoos: barbed wire, Celtic bands, strings of leaves and flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thinking one arm or both?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrists and ankles. But none of these. Just a plain band, like handcuffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sensitive there. Particularly the ankles. It's gonna hurt. That doesn't bother her in the least. She rolls up her sleeves and watches him ready the tattoo gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do one of those cost?

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION IMAGE
dialogues.text: A bland financial announcer reading the news. The graphic to the side of him is the distinctive V.I. logo of Vanger Industries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Petrochemical manufacturer Vanger Industries has acquired a controlling interest in Millennium magazine which according to analysts has been in financial trouble since last December when its cofounder Mikael Blomkvist was found guilty of libel against Hans-Erik Wennerstrom -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A news crew has crammed itself inside Erika's office, where a reporter interviews her -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made a serious mistake last year, and we regret it. But we're moving forward, and this is the first step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't say the first step was your sacking of Mr. Blomkvist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's inaccurate. Read the original press release, Viggo. I didn't fire him. He's on sabbatical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure, to be honest with you.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. COTTAGE
dialogues.text: He's at his desk, the cat in his lap, reviewing the album of photos taken on the day Harriet disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're arranged chronologically, and Vanger has noted the approximate time of day of each. The first several were taken on the manor grounds, by family members of each other. The next couple taken in town of the parade. Then dozens taken on and around the bridge of the dramatic accident. He hears the sound and glances out to see a television news van driving toward Vanger's manor -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crew is set up in the yard by the water, interviewing Henrik and Martin. Under his suit jacket Henrik wears a cheerful yellow shirt. Birger unhappily looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Millennium is an excellent magazine. We also think it's undervalued right now, which is good business for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is any magazine really undervalued today. How many will be around tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another reason.      I don't like bullies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you referring to Mr. Wennerstrom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm referring to anyone who tries to sue their enemies into submission. If Mr. Wennerstrom would like to try it again, he'll find himself fighting a company that can afford to fight back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're enjoying this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already it's the most fun I've had in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a clerk rings up the   items Salander is buying - bright yellow duct tape   and a plastic protective mask - she watches a shot on a   TV here of Wennerstrom being interviewed outside his   offices -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always admired Henrik Vanger. He's a titan - and a gentleman. But he's also quite old now - which may explain how he could be taken in by a convicted liar. The report segues to another story.     The clerk hands Salander her receipt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hardware store purchases, along with some fresh DVD- R's, a couple of plastic bottles of ink, and McDonald's Kids Meal wrappers, sit by her laptop. She's not typing on its keyboard, but characters are appearing nonetheless as someone somewhere else, writes an email: The From box reads:   h wennerstrom <hew@wg.com> The To box reads:   l jansson <ldj@sklaw.com -="" <b="" a </ldj@sklaw.com></hew@wg.com>
